isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - ROCKWELL TANDEM AXLE FORWARD REAR DRIVE UNITS - INSTALL - Checking the Tooth Contact Patterns of the Gear Set

svcproc.title: Checking the Tooth Contact Patterns of the Gear Set

svcsubproc.title: General Information
svcsubproc.para: In the following procedures, movement of the contact pattern along the length of the tooth is indicated as toward the "heel" or "toe" of the ring gear ( Figure 135).

figure.caption: Figure 135. Heel and Toe of Ring Gear

svcsubproc.para: Always check the tooth contact patterns on the drive side of the gear teeth ( Figure 136).

figure.caption: Figure 136. Check Tooth Contact Patterns on Drive Side

step1.para: Adjust the backlash of a new gear set to 0.012 inch (0.30 mm). Adjust the backlash of an old gear set to the setting that was measured before the carrier was disassembled.
Apply a marking compound to approximately 12 gear teeth of the ring gear. Rotate the ring gear so that the 12 gear teeth are next to the drive pinion ( Figure 137).
Rotate the ring gear forward and backward so that the 12 gear teeth go past the drive pinion six times to get the contact pattern. Repeat, if needed, to get a more clear pattern.
Look at the contact patterns on the ring gear teeth. Compare the patterns to Figure 138, Figure 139, and Figure 140.
The location of a good hand-rolled contact pattern for a new gear set is toward the toe of the gear tooth and in the center, between the top and the bottom of the tooth.
When the carrier is being operated under load, the pattern will extend approxi- mately the full length of the tooth. The top of the pattern will be near the top of the gear tooth ( Figure 141).
The location of a good hand-rolled pattern for a used gear set must match the wear pattern in the ring gear. The contact pattern will be smaller in area than the wear pattern.

If the contact pattern requires adjust- ment, continue by following Step 5 to move the contact patterns to a deeper or shallower position on the gear teeth. If contact patterns are in the center of the gear teeth, continue by following Step 6.

Change the thickness of the shim pack between the pinion inner bearing cup and the differential carrier to move the contact patterns between the top and the bottom of the gear teeth. Use the following procedure:

note.para: A high-contact pattern indicates that the drive pinion was not installed deep enough into the carrier. A deep- contact pattern indicates that the drive pinion was installed too far in the carrier.

step2.para: Remove the drive pinion, the inner bearing cup and the shims from the carrier.
To correct a high-contact pattern, increase the thickness of the shim pack. When you increase the thickness of the shim pack, the drive pinion will move toward the ring gear ( Figure 142).
To correct a deep-contact pattern, decrease the thickness of the shim pack. When you decrease the thickness of the shim, the drive pinion will move away from the ring gear ( Figure 143).
Install the inner bearing cup, the shims and the drive pinion into the carrier.
Repeat Steps 2-5 until the contact patterns are in the center between the top and bottom of the gear teeth.

step1.para: Adjust the backlash of the ring gear within the specification range to move the contact patterns to the correct location along the length of the gear teeth.

step2.para: Decrease backlash to move the contact patterns toward the toe of the ring gear teeth ( Figure 144).
Increase backlash to move the contact patterns toward the heel of the ring gear teeth ( Figure 145).
Repeat Steps 2-4 and 6 until the contact patterns are at the correct location along the length of the gear teeth.

figure.caption: Figure 144. Decrease Backlash to Move Contact Patterns Toward Toe
Figure 145. Increase Backlash to Move Contact Patterns Toward Heel

step1.para: After all the adjustments are finally completed, install the lock pin on the bearing cap so that the pin is between the lugs of the adjusting ring.
